abstract.p: March of Dimes president Dr Jennifer L Howse letter lauds June 6 Personal Health column for reminding pregnant women of importance of B vitamin folic acid in preventing birth defects of brain and spinal cord; notes few women know that vitamin should be taken before conception; drawing

block.p: The Personal Health column ''What Could Be Good About Morning Sickness? Plenty'' (June 6) appropriately reminded pregnant women of the importance of the B vitamin folic acid in preventing serious birth defects of the brain and spinal cord.

But the vast majority of the 60 million women of childbearing age in this country still do not know that in order to be effective, the vitamin must be consumed every day beginning before conception and continuing into the first three months of pregnancy.

But the vast majority of the 60 million women of childbearing age in this country still do not know that in order to be effective, the vitamin must be consumed every day beginning before conception and continuing into the first three months of pregnancy.
A nationwide survey conducted by the Gallup Organization for the March of Dimes and released on June 6 found that only 10 percent of women knew that folic acid should be taken before pregnancy.
The writer is president of the March of Dimes.
